snippet: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.
abstract: Schools in Liberia are beginning to reopen after months-long shutdown as Ebola cases continue to decline into single digits, but many are struggling with low attendance and lack of resources; families, still fearful of contracting disease, are reluctant to bring their children in; challenges highlight lingering effects of Ebola, which has depressed Liberia's economy and ravaged its health care system.

byline.contributor: Sheri Fink contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.

headline.main: Back to School, Though Not Back to Normal, in a Liberia Still Fearful of Ebola
headline.print_headline: In Liberia, Heading Back to School, Not Quite Back to Normal
